citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The report of semi-annual evaluations submitted to the Institutional Official on November 8th, 2023 did not contain a
schedule with dates for correcting the minor deficiency identified during the facility inspection. Upon records review during
the inspection, the committee noted a minor deficiency observed during the semi-annual facility inspection on November
1, 2023, but a schedule with dates for correcting this deficiency was not denoted in this record or the November 2023
letter to the Institutional Official.
To help ensure the facility can discharge their responsibilities under the AWA, reports of semi-annual evaluations must
contain a reasonable and specific plan and schedule with dates for correcting each deficiency.
Correct by November 30, 2024.

The facility’s 2023 annual report submitted to USDA did not accurately reflect the number of dogs housed for the 2023
federal fiscal year. The annual report reflects a total of 45 dogs, but the animal inventory from the July 2023 inspection
report denotes 55 adult dogs and 1 puppy were housed at the facility. Though the facility representative informed the
inspector the dogs observed during last year’s July 2023 inspection were dogs that had not begun trials at the facility, the
inspector informed the facility representative there’s a space on the annual report to account for those dogs as well.
Accurate reporting of all animals on the annual report is required to ensure USDA APHIS Animal Care is aware of the
correct number, type, and pain category of animals used, or held for use, in research.
Correct by July 19, 2024.

The outdoor space designated as an exercise pen for two adult dogs did not provide any shelter structures. Though the
facility stated the previous shelter structure had been damaged and would be replaced, a shelter alternative had not been
incorporated in the interim for this space.
One exercise pen in the outdoor park did not provide shelter structures constructed of four sides to accommodate the
dogs housed therein. Though shelter and shade structures were provided in this exercise pen, the shelter structure was
not big enough to accommodate all the dogs present and lacked sides. Per the facility, dogs are usually offered access to
the outdoor park exercise enclosures up to two hours, unless the dogs need to be brought indoors sooner due to weather
conditions or climatic temperatures for that day.
The presence of shelters structures constructed as outlined in this subpart help protect the animals from the elements,
especially wind and increased rainfall, allowing them to remain dry and comfortable. All shelters housing dogs in outdoor
facilities must contain a roof, four sides, a floor, and provide a wind break and rain break at the entrance to help keep the
animals dry and comfortable in their shelter.
Correct by October 4, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the authorized persons.
n

narrative:
2.31(c)(3) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
The report of semi-annual evaluations submitted to the Institutional Official on November 8th, 2023 did not contain a 
schedule with dates for correcting the minor deficiency identified during the facility inspection. Upon records review during 
the inspection, the committee noted a minor deficiency observed during the semi-annual facility inspection on November 
1, 2023, but a schedule with dates for correcting this deficiency was not denoted in this record or the November 2023 
letter to the Institutional Official. 
To help ensure the facility can discharge their responsibilities under the AWA, reports of semi-annual evaluations must 
contain a reasonable and specific plan and schedule with dates for correcting each deficiency. 
 
Correct by November 30, 2024. 
2.36(b)(8) 
   
Annual report. 
The facility’s 2023 annual report submitted to USDA did not accurately reflect the number of dogs housed for the 2023 
federal fiscal year. The annual report reflects a total of 45 dogs, but the animal inventory from the July 2023 inspection 
report denotes 55 adult dogs and 1 puppy were housed at the facility. Though the facility representative informed the 
inspector the dogs observed during last year’s July 2023 inspection were dogs that had not begun trials at the facility, the 
inspector informed the facility representative there’s a space on the annual report to account for those dogs as well. 
Accurate reporting of all animals on the annual report is required to ensure USDA APHIS Animal Care is aware of the 
correct number, type, and pain category of animals used, or held for use, in research.  
 
Correct by July 19, 2024. 
3.4(b) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The outdoor space designated as an exercise pen for two adult dogs did not provide any shelter structures. Though the 
facility stated the previous shelter structure had been damaged and would be replaced, a shelter alternative had not been 
incorporated in the interim for this space.

One exercise pen in the outdoor park did not provide shelter structures constructed of four sides to accommodate the 
dogs housed therein. Though shelter and shade structures were provided in this exercise pen, the shelter structure was 
not big enough to accommodate all the dogs present and lacked sides. Per the facility, dogs are usually offered access to 
the outdoor park exercise enclosures up to two hours, unless the dogs need to be brought indoors sooner due to weather 
conditions or climatic temperatures for that day. 
The presence of shelters structures constructed as outlined in this subpart help protect the animals from the elements, 
especially wind and increased rainfall, allowing them to remain dry and comfortable. All shelters housing dogs in outdoor 
facilities must contain a roof, four sides, a floor, and provide a wind break and rain break at the entrance to help keep the 
animals dry and comfortable in their shelter. 
 
Correct by October 4, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the authorized persons.
